techniques.name: Unauthorized Software In NFVI
techniques.description: An adversary may implant rootkits in the Network Function Virtualization Infrastructure (NFVI) that will hide the presence of programs, files, network connections, services, drivers, and other system components.

techniques.name: Core-network Scanning
techniques.description: An adversary may use scanning tools to discover 5G core network related information (identifiers).

techniques.name: Automated Exfiltration
techniques.description: Adversaries may exfiltrate data, such as sensitive documents, through the use of automated processing after being gathered during Collection.

techniques.name: Network Traffic Duplication
techniques.description: An adversary may use compromised virtualized network elements to (vSwitch, vRouter, Virtual Firewalls) to span traffic to sniffing port for access to user plane and control plane data.

techniques.name: Remote Services
techniques.description: Adversaries may use [Valid Accounts](https://attack.

techniques.name: Masquerading
techniques.description: Adversaries may attempt to manipulate features of their artifacts to make them appear legitimate or benign to users and/or security tools.

techniques.name: Utility Software
techniques.description: Adversaries may deploy their own software with a name to match the name of legitimate firewall utility tool.

techniques.name: PLMN ID
techniques.description: An adversary may use the identifier of a legitimate operator (e.

techniques.name: Port Number
techniques.description: Adversaries may use an unconventional port to obscure illicit communications.

techniques.name: Network Sniffing
techniques.description: Adversaries may sniff network traffic to capture information about an environment, including authentication material passed over the network.

techniques.name: Radio Interface
techniques.description: An adversary may eavesdrop on unencrypted subscriber data on the air interface.

techniques.name: Eavesdrop On O-RAN U Plane Data
techniques.description: Adversary intercepts communications on O-RAN Open Fronthaul interface to sniff U Plane data.

techniques.name: Telecom Protocol
techniques.description: Adversaries may exfiltrate subscriber data by embedding it in a telecommunications protocol also used for C2 (for example GTP, SIGTRAN or external DNS protocol).

techniques.name: Core-network Scanning
techniques.description: Adversaries may scan operator network to discover network services.

techniques.name: Control Plane Signaling Exfiltration
techniques.description: An adversary may use Control Plane signaling between operator-internal Network Functions and externally-facing NFs or proxies to exfiltrate data to external endpoints.

techniques.name: DNS Queries
techniques.description: Adversaries may steal data from an MNO by sending it over allowed DNS requests to DNS servers outside the MNO domain.

techniques.name: Covert Exfiltration Of Data Via DNS Request
techniques.description: An adversary may move targeted data and remain undetected during the exfiltration process by using DNS requests.

techniques.name: Telecom Systems CLI
techniques.description: Adversaries may exploit command and scripting interpreters to abuse API to escalate privileges, navigate the control plane, discover network information, or impact availability.

techniques.name: Application Layer Protocol
techniques.description: Adversaries may communicate using OSI application layer protocols to avoid detection/network filtering by blending in with existing traffic.

techniques.name: SSH
techniques.description: Adversaries may use application layer protocol on an unconventional port to avoid detection or network filtering.

techniques.name: Telecom Protocols
techniques.description: An adversary may use various telecom protocols for Command and Control (C2) to/from a compromised MNO roaming partner network.

techniques.name: 5G Orchestration And Deployment Tools
techniques.description: An adversary may use CI/CD tools to gain access to production hosts/VNFs for discovery, data exfiltration and for deployment of lateral movements tools.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.description: Adversaries may obtain and abuse credentials of existing accounts as a means of gaining Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation, or Defense Evasion.

techniques.name: Network Element
techniques.description: Adversaries may abuse credentials of default accounts set by the factory on networking devices, system assets, or user accounts to gain access or control of the host or NF.

techniques.name: Infrastructure Local Accounts
techniques.description: An adversary may use local administrative privileges to bypass network controls responsible for access controls and software to achieve persistence.

techniques.name: Proxy
techniques.description: Adversaries may use a connection proxy to direct network traffic between systems or act as an intermediary for network communications to a command and control server to avoid direct connections to their infrastructure.

techniques.name: Internal Proxy
techniques.description: Adversaries may use an internal proxy to direct command and control traffic between two or more systems in a compromised environment.

techniques.name: External Proxy
techniques.description: Adversaries may use an external proxy to act as an intermediary for network communications to a C2 server to avoid direct connections to their infrastructure.

techniques.name: Multi-hop Proxy
techniques.description: Adversaries may chain together multiple proxies to disguise the source of malicious traffic.

techniques.name: Brute Force
techniques.description: Adversaries may use brute force techniques to gain access to accounts when passwords are unknown or when password hashes are obtained.

techniques.name: Password Guessing eDNS Server
techniques.description: Adversaries with no prior knowledge of legitimate credentials within the system or environment may guess passwords to attempt access to accounts.

techniques.name: Exploit Public-Facing Network Function
techniques.description: An adversary may exploit weaknesses in Application Programming (API) interfaces on Network Functions (NF) that are exposed to the public Internet, which exposes those functions to compromise of the NF, or disclosure of information.

techniques.name: 5G Supply Chain Compromise
techniques.description: Adversaries may manipulate products or product delivery mechanisms prior to deployment in an MNO's production environment for the purpose of data or system compromise.

techniques.name: Compromise Software Supply Chain
techniques.description: Adversaries may manipulate software products or product delivery mechanisms prior to deployment in an MNO's production environment for the purpose of data or system compromise.

techniques.name: Compromise Hardware Supply Chain
techniques.description: Adversaries may manipulate hardware components or products prior to deployment in an MNO's production environment for the purpose of data or system compromise.

techniques.name: SIM Credentials Theft
techniques.description: An adversary may get access to several SIM credentials either by physical access to SIM card inventory or by compromising SIM data repository.

techniques.name: Compromise Service Supply Chain
techniques.description: Adversaries may manipulate service or service delivery mechanisms prior to or while used by a mobile network operator (MNO), especially those outsourced to third-party managed service providers (MSPs) or managed security service providers (MSSPs), to gain unauthorized access or persistence within the telecom network.

techniques.name: Trusted Relationship
techniques.description: Adversaries may breach or otherwise leverage organizations who have access to intended victims.

techniques.name: MNO Roaming Partners
techniques.description: An adversary may breach or otherwise leverage a mobile network operator's (MNO's) roaming partners or their service partners to gain access to subscriber's services or obtain information about that subscriber from their home network.

techniques.name: Unauthorized Device On O-RAN Fronthaul Infrastructure
techniques.description: An adversary may attach a device to an O-RAN fronthaul infrastructure in order to disrupt its traffic.

techniques.name: Exploitation for Client Execution
techniques.description: Adversaries may exploit software vulnerabilities in client applications to execute code.

techniques.name: Over-the-Air Input
techniques.description: An adversary may send specially crafted data to the UE over-the-air via the radio interface to execute malicious code.

techniques.name: Baseband API
techniques.description: An adversary may send specially crafted data to the UE's application processor's interface to the baseband API to execute malicious code.

techniques.name: Alternate Port Number
techniques.description: Adversaries may use an unconventional port to hide C2 messages.

techniques.name: Compromised rApp Exploits Services
techniques.description: An adversary may use a malicious rApp to exploit the R1 interface for gaining unauthorized access to network configuration and sensitive data.

techniques.name: Network Denial of Service
techniques.description: Adversaries may perform Network Denial of Service (DoS) attacks to degrade or block the availability of targeted resources to users.

techniques.name: TAU Signaling Storm
techniques.description: Adversary controlled false base station transmits crafted broadcast messages to cause signaling storm on legitimate base stations.

techniques.name: Flooding Core Network Component
techniques.description: An adversary may send high volumes of signaling messages to core network functions in order to cause a denial of service.

techniques.name: Shared Slice Common Control Network Function Resource Exhaustion
techniques.description: Adversaries may exhaust common resources of a slice to cause denial of service (service degradation) to all other slices that use the same common resources.

techniques.name: Malicious Packets To Network Functions
techniques.description: An adversary controlled UE or gNB may be used to send crafted NAS or GTP-U messages to crash or slow down the AMF or UPF.

techniques.name: O-RAN Synchronization
techniques.description: Adversary may change the main clock source of PTP in a legitimate gNB to achieve Denial of Service on RAN.

techniques.name: Endpoint Denial of Service
techniques.description: Adversaries may perform Endpoint Denial of Service (DoS) attacks to degrade or block the availability of services to users.

techniques.name: Service Exhaustion Flood
techniques.description: Adversaries may target the different network services provided by systems to conduct a denial of service (DoS).

techniques.name: Consume Data Allocation To Deny Or Degrade Service
techniques.description: A malicious app consumes subscriber data allocation to deny or degrade service to that UE.

techniques.name: Trigger Fraud Alert To Deny Service
techniques.description: An adversary may trigger a fraud alert by sending fake registrations on behalf of a given UE.

techniques.name: DOS A UE Via gNB Or NF Signaling
techniques.description: An adversary controlling a gNB or control plane or user plane core Network Function (NF) may manipulate signaling to result in DoS for one or more UEs.

techniques.name: DOS A UE Via Established GTP-U Tunnel
techniques.description: An adversary may send crafted GTP-U packets to a UE via established user plane to crash or slow down UE.

techniques.name: DOS A UE By GTP-U Exploit To The UPF
techniques.description: Adversary may send crafted GTP-U packets to UPF in order to cause a response from a server that will crash or slow down a UE.

techniques.name: Implant Internal Image
techniques.description: Adversaries may implant cloud or container images with malicious code to establish persistence after gaining access to an environment.

techniques.name: Pre-OS Boot
techniques.description: Adversaries may abuse Pre-OS Boot mechanisms as a way to establish persistence on a system.

techniques.name: Unauthorized Software In NFVI
techniques.description: An adversary may implant malware in the Network Function Virtualization Infrastructure (NFVI) that will load during the pre-boot sequence to achieve persistence.

techniques.name: Credentials from Password Stores
techniques.description: Adversaries may search for common password storage locations to obtain user credentials.

techniques.name: Hardware Security Module Key Signing
techniques.description: Adversaries may gain unauthorized access to a Hardware Security Module (HSM) to sign keys and/or other derived key material that can be used to achieve additional goals.

techniques.name: Adversary-in-the-Middle
techniques.description: Adversaries may attempt to position themselves between two or more networked devices using an adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) technique to support follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.

techniques.name: O-RAN E2Term
techniques.description: Rogue xApp sends spoofed ARP message by impersonating E2Term's IP address thereby causing traffic re-direction from all E2 nodes to rogue xApp.

techniques.name: Radio Interface
techniques.description: An adversary may position itself on the radio interface, to support follow-on behaviors such as Network Sniffing or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](/techniques/FGT1565.

techniques.name: Roaming And Interconnection
techniques.description: An adversary may act as an adversary-in-the-middle (AITM) between two mobile network operators to enable activities like network sniffing (FGT1040) or transmitted data manipulation (FGT1565.

techniques.name: Non-SBI
techniques.description: An adversary with access to Non-Service Based Interfaces (Non-SBI) network nodes (including routers/switches/load balancers) may position themselves in order to support follow-on behaviors such as Network Sniffing or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](/techniques/FGT1565.

techniques.name: Service Based Interface
techniques.description: An adversary in the 5G core who compromised a proxy or middlebox may position themselves between Network Functions (NFs) that are communicating via the Service Based Interfaces (SBI), in order to support follow-on behaviors such as Network Sniffing or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](/techniques/FGT1565.

techniques.name: Impair Defenses
techniques.description: Adversaries may maliciously modify components of a victim environment in order to hinder or disable defensive mechanisms.

techniques.name: External DNS
techniques.description: An adversary uses a wrapper to modify the external DNS (eDNS) firewall and thus evade detection of firewall changes.

techniques.name: Bid Down UE
techniques.description: An adversary may employ a false base station to bid down (downgrade) the victim UE to a less secure Radio Access Network in order to exploit the vulnerabilities in that network.

techniques.name: Hide Artifacts
techniques.description: Adversaries may attempt to hide artifacts associated with their behaviors to evade detection.

techniques.name: Command Output Filtering
techniques.description: An adversary may attempt to disguise communications using malware.

techniques.name: Data Manipulation
techniques.description: Adversaries may insert, delete, or manipulate data in order to influence external outcomes or hide activity, thus threatening the integrity of the data.

techniques.name: Transmitted Data Manipulation
techniques.description: Adversaries may alter data en route to storage or other systems in order to manipulate external outcomes or hide activity, thus threatening the integrity of the data.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over Web Service
techniques.description: Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service to exfiltrate data rather than their primary command and control channel.

techniques.name: Exfiltration To Public Cloud
techniques.description: Adversaries may exfiltrate data to a cloud storage service rather than over their primary command and control channel.

techniques.name: DNS Encapsulation
techniques.description: An adversary may piggyback user data within DNS requests, so that the DNS server retrieves the user data for further processing.

techniques.name: UE Access Via GTP-U
techniques.description: An adversary may send crafted GTP-U packets to the UPF/PGW-U in order to establish an illicit session with a target UE.

techniques.name: C2 Over GTP-U
techniques.description: Adversary establishes a C2 tunnel to a server it controls, using GTP-U.

techniques.name: Access To Cloud Infrastructure Or MEC
techniques.description: An adversary may purchase access to cloud infrastructure or Multi-access Edge Computing (MEC) resources that will also be hosting the operator's infrastructure.

techniques.name: False Base Station Or Access Point
techniques.description: An adversary may purchase, rent, or download software to stand up a false base station (gNB or gNB emulator) or WiFi access point in order to pave the way to other follow-on behaviors against UEs such as adversary in the middle, denial of service, data interception or manipulation.

techniques.name: Programmable UE Devices
techniques.description: An adversary may purchase, rent, or download software to acquire a programmable User Equipment (UE) device, in order to pave the way to other follow-on behaviors against the Radio-Access Network (RAN) such as denial of service.

techniques.name: Network Access
techniques.description: An adversary obtains use of network or signaling infrastructure in order to apply techniques against 5G networks or UEs.

techniques.name: Develop Capabilities
techniques.description: Adversaries may build capabilities that can be used during targeting.

techniques.name: Baseband Exploits
techniques.description: An adversary may develop exploits that target the UE to execute malicious code.

techniques.name: Operator Network
techniques.description: An adversary may create an operator network to facilitate applying techniques to a victim UE.

techniques.name: Obtain Capabilities
techniques.description: Adversaries may buy and/or steal capabilities that can be used during targeting.

techniques.name: Telecom
techniques.description: An adversary may buy, steal or download capabilities needed to target network elements and User Equipment.

techniques.name: Radio Network Functions
techniques.description: An adversary may obtain radio network function needed to attack target victim UEs.

techniques.name: Gather Victim Host Information
techniques.description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's hosts that can be used during targeting.

techniques.name: Internal Resource Search
techniques.description: An adversary may gain access to an operator's roaming database (IR.

techniques.name: Compromise Network Isolation
techniques.description: An adversary may compromise network separation controls to gain access to one or more of the 5G security zones or networks.

techniques.name: Malicious Co-Tenancy Exploit Of NFVI (Network Slice)
techniques.description: Adversaries may gain unauthorized access to information via a Virtual Network Function (VNF) shared for service designed for two different slices.

techniques.name: Network Slice Infrastructure Resource Hijacking
techniques.description: Adversaries may use a less secure slice to gain access to information in a more secure slice that uses the VNF (Common VNF) built on common infrastructure to misuse resources allocated to target VNFs or slice.

techniques.name: GTP-U Abuse
techniques.description: An adversary-controlled UE may be used to send a GTP-U packet to UPF/PGW-U with a malicious payload in order to evade UPF/PGW-U routing controls to establish communications with a core NF.

techniques.name: Weaken Encryption
techniques.description: Adversaries may compromise a network device's encryption capability in order to bypass encryption that would otherwise protect data communications.

techniques.name: Radio Interface
techniques.description: An adversary may alter network signaling or configuration so as to disable encryption over the radio interface, thus allowing for eavesdropping of user data or signaling on that interface.

techniques.name: Network Interfaces
techniques.description: An adversary may weaken or disable encryption on Non-SBI, SBI, and roaming interfaces, enabling eavesdropping on user data or signaling.

techniques.name: Rogue Operator Network
techniques.description: An adversary may install or set up a customized core mobile network in a target environment to enable follow-on behaviors.

techniques.name: Configurability Of False Base Station Or Access Point
techniques.description: An adversary may obtain software to configure a false base station (gNB or gNB emulator) or WiFi access point in order to enable other Radio Access Network (RAN) follow-on behaviors against UEs such as adversary in the middle or denial of service.

techniques.name: Configure Operator Core Network
techniques.description: An adversary may operationalize a customized mobile network in a target environment to enable other follow-on behaviors against UEs.

techniques.name: Container Administration Command
techniques.description: Adversaries may abuse a container administration service to execute commands within a container.

techniques.name: Accessing Terminated VNF
techniques.description: An adversary may use an NFVI controller to gain access to data from a suspended or stopped VNF to extract sensitive information.

techniques.name: VM And Container Breakout
techniques.description: Adversary may be able to break out of VM/Container to host to compromise co-resident tenant VM/Container for discovery and exfiltration and host-based privilege escalation.

techniques.name: Malicious Privileged container-VNF Shared Resource Access
techniques.description: An adversary may compromise a target Virtual Network Function (VNF) to gain unauthorized access to the data from the underlying resources shared with other VNFs.

techniques.name: Endpoint Denial of Service
techniques.description: Adversaries may perform Endpoint Denial of Service (DoS) attacks to degrade or block the availability of services to users.

techniques.name: Transmit Spoofed Broadcast Message
techniques.description: Adversary controlled false base station transmits crafted broadcast messages to prevent legitimate UEs to connect to network.

techniques.name: UE
techniques.description: An adversary may send a crafted signaling message to the UE to cause it to fail its attach procedure.

techniques.name: AMF
techniques.description: An adversary may send a crafted signaling message to the AMF to cause it to fail its service or attach request.

techniques.name: Network-side SMS Collection
techniques.description: An adversary may compromise the operator's SMS Center (SMSC) to collect SMS messages to/from the UEs.

techniques.name: Bypass Home Routing
techniques.description: An adversary positioned in an operator network may send an SMS delivery location query that will bypass the SMS home router of another operator, allowing the adversary to get the location of the user device.

techniques.name: Network Function Service Discovery
techniques.description: An adversary may query the Network Repository Function (NRF) to discover restricted Network Function (NF) services to further target that NF.

techniques.name: Network Flow Manipulation
techniques.description: An adversary may discover Software Defined Network (SDN) flow information, which could then be used for lateral movement and unauthorized changes in the network.

techniques.name: Controller
techniques.description: An adversary may use the compromised SDN controller or Control plane API to modify network flow rules, or traffic management policies.

techniques.name: vSwitch
techniques.description: An adversary may compromise a vSwitch in an SDN network to manipulate the network traffic or cause denial of service An SDN vSwitch is like a layer 2 switch that connects devices to the network and performs packet forwarding between the switch ports.

techniques.name: Memory Scraping
techniques.description: An adversary may be able to read memory registers to discover privileged information such as local password comparison, encryption key etc.

techniques.name: Registration Of Malicious Network Functions
techniques.description: An adversary, such as an insider to the MNO or vendor, may install a malicious NF into the core network, in order to launch other attacks or get access to information.

techniques.name: Redirection Of Traffic Via User Plane Network Function
techniques.description: An adversary may divert user plane traffic for one or more UEs via a user-plane function, to monitor user data.

techniques.name: Weaken Integrity
techniques.description: An adversary may compromise a network device's integrity capability or configuration in order to exploit the non-integrity protected data communication.

techniques.name: Radio Interface
techniques.description: An adversary may alter or spoof network signaling so as to enable the NULL integrity algorithm thus allowing for manipulation of user data or signaling over the radio interface, for example to redirect traffic.

techniques.name: Network Interfaces
techniques.description: An adversary may change the configuration of network nodes so as to disable or weaken integrity protection on the network interfaces Non-SBI, SBI and Roaming, thus allowing for transmitted data manipulation.

techniques.name: Fraudulent AMF Registration For UE In UDM
techniques.description: An adversary-controlled AMF may register itself in the UDM as the serving network for a victim's UE, enabling further attacks like fraud or the retrieval of the UE's subscription data.

techniques.name: Unauthorized Access To Network Exposure Function (NEF) Via Token Fraud
techniques.description: An adversary controlling an (external) Application Function (AF) may present a fraudulent OAuth access token to access Network Exposure Function (NEF) services.

techniques.name: Locate UE
techniques.description: An adversary may obtain the UE location using radio access or core network or the roaming fabric.

techniques.name: Passive Radio Signals Observation
techniques.description: An adversary may non-cooperatively geolocate a UE from UE radio signal externals.

techniques.name: UE Measurement Reports
techniques.description: An adversary may elicit location reports from a UE that is bid down to a less secure protocol or may passively observe location reports from UE whose air interface traffic is not encrypted.

techniques.name: 5G-GUTI Reuse
techniques.description: An adversary can track a device (get cell-level location) by listening for the same temporary identifier being sent to the network.

techniques.name: Core Network Function Signaling
techniques.description: An adversary in the core network exploits signaling protocols to obtain the location of the UE.

techniques.name: Shared Network Function In Slice
techniques.description: An adversary may use a legitimate access token for a shared Network Function (NF) to get location info of a user of a different network slice.

techniques.name: NAS Exploit
techniques.description: An adversary may geolocate a UE using modified Non-Access Stratum (NAS) signaling, for example via a false base station.

techniques.name: Silent Or Spoofed Paging
techniques.description: Adversary sends spoofed or silent paging messages to a UE and deduces the UE's location from the responses of that UE.

techniques.name: SS7 Or Diameter Signaling
techniques.description: An adversary may send an unsolicited SS7/Diameter message to the core network of a UE that will cause the core network to provide coarse location of the UE.

techniques.name: Malicious VNF Instantiation
techniques.description: An adversary may use a fake or compromised container management controller to deploy fake VNFs to collect information from the network.

techniques.name: Shared Resource Discovery
techniques.description: An adversary running a malicious Virtual Network Function (VNF) may identify network resources co-resident on the same physical host.

techniques.name: Device Database Manipulation
techniques.description: An adversary may compromise the Equipment Identity Register (EIR) function and add new equipment, modify status (ok vs.

techniques.name: Abuse Of Inter-operator Interfaces
techniques.description: An adversary exploits interconnection/interworking between MNOs to obtain information about roaming user sessions or commit fraud.

techniques.name: Charging Data Record (CDR) Collection
techniques.description: Adversary may compromise the 5G Charging Function (CHF) in order to steal sensitive subscriber call related data/CDRs.

techniques.name: Vandalism Of Network Infrastructure
techniques.description: An adversary aims to destroy, expose, alter, disable, steal, or gain access to physical assets such as infrastructure, hardware, or interconnection, affecting Quality of Service (QoS) or service availability.

techniques.name: Cabling And Junction Boxes
techniques.description: An adversary targets unprotected cables and junction boxes in order to disrupt service.

techniques.name: Radio Access Hardware
techniques.description: An adversary uses unrestricted access to exploit, damage, or destroy Radio Access hardware that lack adequate security.

techniques.name: Edge Servers
techniques.description: An adversary may seek physical access to isolated/remote edge servers using covert methods of entry with the intent to damage or destroy edge computing facilities, gaining unauthorized access at system level as an entry point to all hosted resources, theft of data on local storage, vandalism, and sabotage.

techniques.name: Theft Of Assets
techniques.description: An adversary accesses a shared site, or remote location, with intent to steal valuable materials (such as copper, batteries, and fuel) for resale.

techniques.name: Subscriber Profile Identifier Discovery
techniques.description: An adversary may obtain a UE permanent identifier via various means.

techniques.name: Intercept Home Network Via SUCI
techniques.description: An adversary may intercept unencrypted radio transmissions of a UE's SUCI to identify the home network of the UE.

techniques.name: Intercept Bid-Down SUPI
techniques.description: An adversary may intercept the UE permanent identifier (SUPI) from a UE that is bid down to a less secure protocol.

techniques.name: Obtain Subscriber Identifier Via NF
techniques.description: An adversary in control of an Application Function (AF) or a rogue Network Function (NF) can make an API call to obtain the Subscriber Permanent Identifier (SUPI) or other sensitive UE information.

techniques.name: Intercept Unencrypted SUPI
techniques.description: An adversary may intercept unencrypted radio transmissions of a UE's SUCI to identify the IMSI/SUPI of the UE.

techniques.name: SS7 Or Diameter Signaling
techniques.description: An adversary may send an unsolicited SS7/Diameter message to the core network of a UE that will cause the core network to provide IMSI/SUPI of the UE.

techniques.name: Silent SMS
techniques.description: Adversary sends a spoofed or silent SMS to trigger paging of UE, to retrieve the subscriber profile identifier.

techniques.name: Retrieve UE Subscription Data
techniques.description: Adversary controlling a control plane network function (NF) may manipulate signaling to retrieve UE subscription information.

techniques.name: Tunnel ID Uniqueness Failure
techniques.description: An adversary controlling a user-plane function (gNB or UPF) may disrupt user traffic by assigning the new traffic a TEID already in use.

techniques.name: Alter Subscriber Profile
techniques.description: An adversary may alter the subscriber profile to achieve fraud, via SBI (Service Based Interfaces) or OA&M interfaces.

techniques.name: Charging Fraud Via NF Control
techniques.description: An adversary controlling a control plane network function (NF) may manipulate signaling or parameters to achieve charging/billing fraud where victim is UE or operator itself.

techniques.name: IAB Denial Of Service
techniques.description: Adversary may jam the wireless backhaul facility to disrupt the ability to connect to the network for all UEs or Integrated Access and Backhaul (IAB) nodes.

techniques.name: Falsify Interconnect Invoice
techniques.description: An adversary in a roaming partner operator may send altered service usage for a given UE to the home operator of that UE.

techniques.name: SIM Cloning
techniques.description: Adversary may clone a SIM card (namely the SUPI, credential stored therein) and use it fraudulently to obtain telecom service at the expense of the user of the device with that legitimate SIM card.

techniques.name: Spoof Network Slice Identifier
techniques.description: An adversary controlling a Network Function (NF) or slice may gain access to a different network slice data by interacting with other NFs.

techniques.name: Discover Network Slice Identifier
techniques.description: An adversary may guess the identifier of a network slice, which allows for follow-on behaviors against that slice that require that identifier.

techniques.name: Exploit Semi-public Facing Application
techniques.description: Adversary sends specifically crafted messages from an interconnect/interworking partner against roaming interface to gain access to the service function, e.

techniques.name: Discover Tunnel Endpoint ID (TEID)
techniques.description: An adversary may discover a valid GTP-U TEID in order to apply additional techniques.

techniques.name: gNodeB Component Manipulation
techniques.description: An adversary may compromise a component of gNodeB to affect radio network configuration.

techniques.name: RAN Intelligent Controller (RIC)
techniques.description: An adversary may compromise a RAN Intelligent Controller (RIC) to affect radio network configuration.

techniques.name: xApp
techniques.description: An adversary may compromise an xApp to affect the radio network configuration.

techniques.name: rApp
techniques.description: An adversary may compromise an rApp to affect the radio network configuration.

techniques.name: Radio Control Manipulation Via Rogue xApps
techniques.description: Malicious xApps may gain unauthorized access to near-RT RIC and E2 nodes, in order to affect Radio Access Network (RAN) behavior.

techniques.name: O-RAN E2Mgr Unauthorized Access
techniques.description: Rogue xApps may bypass authentication and authorization by using unsecured APIs to cause degradation in the RAN.

techniques.name: Radio Reception Degradation
techniques.description: An adversary transmits radio signals to degrade reception of transmissions to the UE or gNB.

techniques.name: AI/ML Training Data And Prediction Poisoning
techniques.description: Adversary may use AI/ML training data and prediction poisoning techniques to manipulate the outcomes of a machine learning model for malicious purposes, to disrupt service or change the behavior of network elements.

techniques.name: Alter ML Model
techniques.description: Adversary may gain unauthorized access to machine learning model or database and alters the data to disrupt service or change the behavior of network elements.

techniques.name: Network Slice Application Resource Hijacking
techniques.description: An adversary may use compromised container management SW (or account) in MANO domain to gain access to target VNFs and its resources for unauthorized access to resources/data of another slice in NFVI or resource exhaustion of target application resulting in denial of service.

techniques.name: Manipulate Virtual Network Function (VNF) Configuration
techniques.description: Adversaries may bridge network boundaries by modifying a Virtual Network Function's Configuration.

techniques.name: Discover Operator Private Key
techniques.description: Adversary sends many arbitrary but cryptographically weak SUCI values in registration requests in order to discover private key of MNO using information received from failure/success responses.

techniques.name: DOS An NF Via Deregistration
techniques.description: Adversary sends fake SBI message to NRF to de-register a legitimate NF from 5G network.

techniques.name: Bypass Telecom Signaling Firewall
techniques.description: Adversary uses GTP echo request message to bypass telecom signaling application-layer firewall and so obtain and maintain unauthorized access.

techniques.name: Unauthorized Access To Core Network Function Via Token Abuse
techniques.description: An adversary may use an OAuth2.

techniques.name: Exploit OAuth2 Scope
techniques.description: Adversary exploits OAuth2.

techniques.name: Force Generation Of Subscriber Keys
techniques.description: An adversary may attempt to subvert the roaming authentication process by forcing the home network to derive and send keys for a victim UE.

techniques.name: Telecom Protocol Payload
techniques.description: Adversaries may hide their data within a legitimate telecom protocol payload in order to evade defenses such as firewall measures.

techniques.name: Program Wrapper
techniques.description: Adversaries may create or modify system-level processes to retain access, prevent detection, and open communication paths with C2 servers and new targets.
